root.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: "Tibeto-Burman and Karen are regarded as constituting a superfamily (Tibeto-Karen) standing in opposition to Chinese. The relationship between Tibeto-Karen and Chinese is a distant one." (p. 2)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: "The Tibeto-Burman languages, over one hundred of which have been recorded, make up the linguistic 'center of gravity' of the Sino-Tibetan stock. There are 7 primary divisions or nuclei of Tibeto-Burman. Immediate genetic relationship must be inferred for the several languages within each nucleus, and somewhat less immediate relationship for other languages mentioned in connection therewith." (pp. 4-5)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0
Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Bahing-Vayu is a "relatively compact unit." "Bahing is the best known of a number of little differentiated languages and dialects of Nepal - the Kiranti languages of Hodgson." (p. 5)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0
Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Vayu stands "fairly close to the Kiranti nucleus." (p. 5)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Newari, the old state language of Nepal, shows many points of divergence and cannot be directly grouped with Bahing and Vayu. (pp. 5-6)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0
Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.codes: ybi, ybi-tmx, tdh, rav, raq, emg, raf, dus, lii, kle, klr, aph, bhj, aph
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0
Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Chepang stands "fairly close to the Kiranti nucleus." (p. 5)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Abor-Miri-Dafla is "a relatively compact unit." (p. 5)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: "The Mishmi tribes of North Assam show linguistic cleavage into Digaro and Miju, both with rather vaguely defined resemblances to Abor-Miri-Dafla and Aka." (p. 6)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0
Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0
Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: "The Mishmi tribes of North Assam show linguistic cleavage into Digaro and Miju, both with rather vaguely defined resemblances to Abor-Miri-Dafla and Aka." (p. 6)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Bodo-Garo is "a relatively compact unit." (p. 5)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Chairel is "preserved only in a word-list by McCulloch (1859)." (p. 7)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0
Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0
Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: "'Naked Naga' (Konyak) languages of the northern Assam-Burma frontier region are most profitably compared with Bodo-Garo, though some of the easternmost members of the group (moshang and Shangge, in Needham 1897) show points of contact with Kachin." (pp. 6-7)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0
Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Kuki-Naga is "made up of a long series of closely related languages and dialects with numerous cross-ties in all directions." (p. 10)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Mikir "shows numerous Kuki-Naga correspondences, yet is sufficiently distinct to be listed as separate linguistic entities." (p. 10)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: "The old Kuki languages are spoken by 'marginal' tribes which have been driven out of the Chin and Lushei Hills by the more vigorous Kuki peoples, notably the Lushei. They represent a somewhat archaic variety of a fundamental Kuki type which has given rise to the Central and Northern Kuki languages. The Southern Kuki group, especially Khami, stands somewhat apart from this basic type." (p. 10)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Sopvoma (or Mao) "exhibits some Kuki features." (p. 10)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0
Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Meithei "shows numerous Kuki-Naga correspondences, yet is sufficiently distinct to be listed as separate linguistic entities." (p. 10)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Tangkhul "stands somewhat closer to the basic Kuki type." (p. 10)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Mru "shows numerous Kuki-Naga correspondences, yet is sufficiently distinct to be listed as separate linguistic entities." (p. 10)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Khoibu is "of transitional Tangkhul-Kuki type." (p. 10)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Poeron "approaches Tangkhul in some respects, but its correct classification remains in doubt." (p. 10)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Maring is "of transitional Tangkhul-Kuki type." (p. 10)

child.pub-comments: This belongs to the major subtype of Himalayish. (p. 7)

child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Kanauri typifies "a major subtype of Himalayish." (p. 7)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: This belongs to the major subtype of Himalayish. (p. 7)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: This belongs to the major subtype of Himalayish. (p. 7)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Zhang-zhung is "an extinct langauge known only from a Tun-huang manuscript." (p. 7) It appears to have been "an early representative of the Kanauri subtype." (p. 7)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0
Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: This belongs to the minor subtype of Himalayish, found in the state of Almora. (p. 7)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: This belongs to the minor subtype of Himalayish, found in the state of Almora. (p. 7)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: This belongs to the minor subtype of Himalayish, found in the state of Almora. (p. 7)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: This belongs to the minor subtype of Himalayish, found in the state of Almora. (p. 7)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: "Magari (Beames) has been extensively influenced by Indic, shows interesting lexical agreements with Bahing-Vayu (especially Vayu and Chepang), and might be regarded as a Bodish-Bahing link." (p. 8)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: "Dzorgai, the 'Outside Man-tze' of Lacouperie (Languages of China), is not sufficiently well known for more detailed classification." (p. 8)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Lepcha (or Rong) "exhibits many of the transitional qualities of Kachin," and "might equally well be regarded as a separate nucleus linking Tibetan-Kanauri with Bahing-Vayu and groups on the south." (pp. 7-8)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0
Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: "Burmese-Lolo takes the form of a vast net of languages and dialects spread over a wide area in China (Szuchuan and Yünnan), Burma, Thailand, Laos and Vietnam." (p. 8)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: Nung "stands fairly close to the Burmese-Lolo nucleus, yet has numberous points of contact with Kachin." (p. 8)
child.geography: Upper reaches of the Nmai Kha valley (northern Irrawaddy drainage)

child.pub-comments: Hsi-hsia was "spoken during the 11th and 12th centuries" (p. 8). "It is not unlikely that Hsi-hsia is ancestral to at least some of the Hsi-fan languages, as suggested by the geographical factors involved (p. 9).

child.pub-comments: Pyu is "the language of a pre-Burmese people of Burma, probably to be identified with the P'iao of the Chinese annals. The extremely fragmentary nature of the Pyu inscriptions, which have been studied by C.O. Blagden, discourages any attempt at precise classification. The material brought to light thus far suggests a rapprochement with Nung rather than with Burmese-Lolo proper." (pp. 9-10)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0
Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0

child.pub-comments: "Pai-lang, which appears in the form of short texts in the 'Hou Han Shu' (3rd century A.D.), must take precedence over Tibetan and Burmese as the earliest recorded Tibeto-burman language. Pai-lang presents formidable problems of interpretation, which have been only partially solved. The Burmese-Lolo characteristics of the lanuage are sufficiently clear, but the numerous and striking phonetic peculiarities demand further attention." (p. 9)
child.publications: Benedict, Paul K. 1972. Sino-Tibetan: A Conspectus. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-08175-0
